mods:mods.abstract: One of the major challenges in stellar evolution theory is to understand how massive stars die. Most massive stars ($M > 8M_\odot$) undergo core collapse at the end of their lives. Some explode as a Core-collapse Supernova explosion, leaving behind a neutron star (NS), while others fail to explode and collapse to a black hole (BH). Understanding what is the explosion mechanism and predicting which massive stars explode have been two main questions in CCSN theory for decades. Answering these questions is key in understanding nucleosynthesis, NS and BH formation and distributions. To develop a better understanding of the explosion mechanism we develop: 1. an analytic theory of which stars explode and which collapse to BH and 2. develop a next-generation CCSN-simulation code~-~ Phoebus. We first derive an analytic theory for the explosion condition in spherical symmetry. This explosion condition is called the force explosion condition (FEC) and considers the imbalance of forces needed to for a successful explosion; dominant effects are neutrino heating and gravitational forces. We tested the FEC in three different ways. In the first, we compared the FEC with the semi-analytic, steady-state solutions of \cite{BURROWS1993}. In the second, we tested it with one-dimensional (1D) CCSN simulations with light-bulb neutrino approximation. In the third, we tested it with 1D radiation-hydrodynamic simulations. The FEC has passed all of these tests which indicates that it is an accurate measure of the explodability of spherical CCSN explosions. State-of-the-art simulations show that successful CCSN explosions require additional multi-dimensional effects, in particular neutrino-driven convection and turbulent dissipation. Motivated by the success of the spherical FEC, we generalized the simple model by including these important multi-dimensional effects. This generalized condition is called the FEC+ and promises to predict explodability of multi-dimensional simulations. Adding multi-dimensional effects in the model generates two additional terms that make the critical threshold for multi-dimensional simulations $\sim 25 \%$ smaller compared to 1D simulations. This matches the results of previous multi-dimensional simulations. Another important key is to develop fast multi-dimensional CCSN simulations that enable parametric studies using three-dimensional (3D) simulations. This is now possible with next-generation GPU capable codes. We develop Phoebus~-~ a GPU-capable code that solves the GR MHD equations and includes a wide array of neutrino transport capabilities, including moments and Monte Carlo transport. Phoebus is an improvement both in terms of physics and performance. It enables CCSN simulations that complete $10-100$ times faster than current multi-dimensional simulations. This will enable us to perform long-overdue systematic studies of the explosion mechanism as well as to test the analytic predictions with series of 3D explosions.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Jeremiah W. Murphy, Professor Directing Dissertation; Eric P. Chassignet, University Representative; Kevin Huffenberger, Committee Member; Peter Hoeflich, Committee Member; Harrison B. Prosper, Committee Member.
